oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Lionel Cartwright Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Lionel Cartwright (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Lionel Cartwright; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Lionel Cartwright talks about working with Don Schlitz and purposely getting sent to his room to listen to a radio he had snuck in (inspiration for "I Watched It All [On My Radio]") -- (01:38) "Old Coal Town" is discussed by Cartwright as about his determination to talk about Marshall County, West Virginia -- (02:28) Biff Collie and Cartwright discuss "Playing It Safe" to which Cartwright calls it a "tricky" song about people who shy away from risks -- (03:22) Collie and Cartwright talk about the previous time Cartwright was on the Music City Album Review -- (03:56) Cartwright reflects on his love of country music and how he had been playing for twenty years -- (04:38) Collie congratulates Cartwright on his first million single "Give Me His Last Chance" and Cartwright reflects on playing in the middle of nowhere -- (05:18) Cartwright tells of how he entered his marriage in the same mind set as "In the Long Run" -- (06:08) Cartwright talks about the pressures of travel and success -- (06:32) Collie introduces Cartwright as a disc jockey and Cartwright speaks about his longing to do another performance as a disc jockey -- (06:57) "Say It's Not True" is introduced by Collie and Cartwright talks on the marriage between the lyrics and melody -- (07:44) Collie and Cartwright confirm their desire to have songs pulled from everyday life -- (08:18) Cartwright talks about the desire to put truth into lyrics and Collie remarks about the midway point of the Music City Album Review -- (08:31) Cartwright speaks about working with the WWVA Jamboree and the I-40 Paradise -- (09:52) Cartwright talks about meeting Tony Brown, writing for MCA records and the excitement of Nashville -- (10:48) Collie introduces "I Refuse To Sing the Blues" and Cartwright and Collie discuss their relationship with Moon Mullican -- (11:40) "My Heart Is Set on You" is introduced and discussed as a homage to the Everly Brothers -- (12:43) Cartwright talks about playing live and the lyrical theme behind "My Heart Is Set on You" being based on Cartwright's wife -- (13:39) "Let's Try Again" is introduced by Collie and Cartwright calls it a positive take of relationships -- (14:29) Collie retells a tale of a farmer -- (15:26) "Hard Act to Follow" is talked about as two gentlemen who were dumped by the same girl -- (16:46) "True Believer" is the opening song for Cartwright's live shows and a reflection of the positives of relationships -- (18:11) Cartwright talks about being a true believer of love -- (18:39) Collie thanks Cartwright and Cartwright reflects on being a disc jockey
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Cartwright, Lionel; Collie, Biff;
